data.text: An extremely stable, ball-shaped carbon molecule, C<sub>60</sub>, reminiscent of a geodesic dome, and believed to occur naturally in soot. It was the first fullerene to be discovered.
data.attributionText: from The American HeritageÂ® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: an <xref>allotrope</xref> of <xref>carbon</xref> having a <xref>hollow</xref> <xref>molecule</xref> consisting of 60 <xref>atoms</xref> arranged in 12 <xref>pentagonal</xref> and 20 <xref>hexagonal</xref> <xref>faces</xref> to form a <xref>truncated</xref> <xref>icosahedron</xref>; the smallest of the <xref>fullerenes</xref>
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: a spheroidal fullerene; the first known example of a fullerene
data.attributionText: from WordNet 3.0 Copyright 2006 by Princeton University. All rights reserved.
